guide.title: Gentoo Managers' Meeting Summary
guide.subtitle: 9 Feb. 2004
guide.author: Grant Goodyear
guide.abstract:
This meeting began at 1800 UTC, and the guest chair was Grant Goodyear. The agenda items included a discussion of the proper use of -fPIC across the various architectures and a proposal of how to limit the use of suid/sgid binaries. The raw
log is available.

chapter.title: The proper role of -fPIC in CFLAGS

body.p: On systems that provide shared libraries a cardinal rule is that code which ends up in a shared library should be compiled as position-independent code (PIC), while code which ends up in an executable should definitely not be compiled as PIC. The resolution of this problem seems simple enough: if a package provides a shared library then CFLAGS should contain -fPIC, while if a package provides only executables then CFLAGS should not contain -fPIC. The problem, of course, occurs when a program provides both shared libraries and executables. In that case the package's build process should be smart enough to know what do when. This issue has arisen because on some non-x86 architectures the apparent fix to various obscure compiler errors has been to add -fPIC to the global CFLAGS. The true fix, of course, is to fix the makefiles.

chapter.title: Should suid/sgid files be (nearly) verboten in Gentoo?

body.p: Suid and guid files allow ordinary users to run programs with elevated permissions. As such, these files invariably are potential security holes. Unfortunately, on *nix systems they are also quite necessary, with the passwd executable being a prime example of a command that users run that itself requires root permissions to do its job. Portage already contains code to flag suid/ sgid files, and solar has proposed that before a package is allowed to merge suid/sgid files into the filesystem those files should first be reviewed by a group of Gentoo security wonks. Additional proposals include creating a list of Gentoo- allowed s[gu]id files, and having portage strip the s[gu]id flags from files unless an ebuild has RESTRICT='setid' set.

The issue of ebuild signing was raised, and it seems that signing- support is mostly in portage at the moment. An additional discussion involved how to make the gcc ebuild more adaptable for people working on hardened-gcc. The meeting officially adjourned at 1930 UTC, but informal discussions continued until 2013 UTC.
